snippet.title: Decorated new chancellor appointed to university
snippet.content: THE University of the Sunshine Coast turned over a new leaf yesterday with the welcoming of a new chancellor. Air Chief Marshal Sir Angus Houston AK, AFC (Ret'd) was formally appointed by the Governor of Queensland, Paul de Jersey AC and will ensure USC works towards its goals. He will also lead the USC's governing Council and be responsible for strategic and governance oversight. Sir Angus, who was chief of the Australian Defence Force from 2005 to 2011, is the university's fourth chancellor and was preceded by John Dobson OAM who served in the position for a decade. His notable achievements since he began working closely with USC in 2011 include being a driving force behind the establishment of the Sunshine Coast Mind and Neuroscience - Thompson Institute as chair of USC's QMNI Foundation Board. Sir Angus has also helped the university work towards becoming a leader in community mental health. Other previous chancellors include Ian Kennedy AO who served from 1998 to 2007 and retired Justice Tony Fitzgerald QC from 1994 to 1998. Work on next stage of redevelopment due to start next April Coast's $18m rescue chopper has been shifted by Lifeflight Scholarship valued at up to $10,000 LIFESTYLE lure was stronger than a high-flying accountancy career. Sunshine Coast Jazz Club is set to present Diamonds of Swing Caloundra Chorale and Theatre Co is gearing up for The Secret Garden Box of Birds art exhibition is coming to Art Nuvo, Buderim A NATIONAL exhibition of ceramic art has been launched on the Coast BREAKING: New festival coming to the Sunshine Coast ONE of Hollywood's most adorable couples is over. New celebrity cooking show fails to fire for Seven. The legendary creator isn't so sure about how Netflix works. *WARNING this story contains spoilers* Make way for Mackay's newest tech start up Planning documents lodged on behalf of site owners Education, student accommodation, bars and music all key to future Five dates through August for community to have its say on rock wall
